content: Hey folks, I would like to review some of the survey data. Is it accessible in any form that would allow me to do that? What do we think about the privacy implications thereof? :)
Can't speak to the privacy implications directly, but @rylev does have a copy where I stripped out the personally identifiable answers.
I would be interested in getting access to data-without-PII as well.

@simulacrum do we need to check with Aaron to make sure that we‚Äôre good with sharing. My understanding is that sharing the data minus PII would be fine from a legal standpoint. However, we don‚Äôt really have a good procedure for who should have access to data and who shouldn‚Äôt. While the members of this chat are obvious choices, I wonder if we need to be explicit about who we attend to give access to this data. I personally would like to see this made completely open, but it strikes me as something I shouldn‚Äôt necessarily be deciding on the fly.

I think the perspective I have typically taken is that /everyone/ largely wants to make this more open, but doing so in a way that's more principled is probably best -- e.g., I would probably recommend we write up an RFC or similar style document that says 'who we share data with' for Rust project surveys -- the data is obviously valuable and useful. I suspect it's not entirely de-personal no matter what we do, so I would be hesitant to endorse a public sharing, especially after the fact. I think we largely promised to not share raw data, so to the extent we can keep that and iterate for future surveys, IMO we should.

To the extent Rust teams have interest in asking questions of the data, I imagine answering those by proxy is possible, though obviously not a complete solution.

I suspect it's not entirely de-personal no matter what we do

Agreed on that front; it's entirely likely that it'll be possible to to deanonymize, even ignoring free-text fields and things like stylometry.

I think there are three tiers here: "what could we share publicly", "what could we share with Rust team members who agree not to share raw data, only summaries meeting constraints XYZ", and then the full data shared only to the survey team under strict PII-protecting NDA.

I'll also note that there has been (and presumably only increasingly so) interest in the data, raw or not, from various companies -- so that's another dimension, where we have to consider the merits of sharing (or not) and how to best structure that sharing in a way that doesn't prevent people from being open to filling it out etc.

The various dimensions and interests here are significant enough that I would want a policy doc written up that we could point to before sharing beyond the 'PII group' which is somewhat unavoidable.
Complete support there. And in particular, we would not want "sharing with Rust team members" to equate to "sharing in part with the companies employing those team members".

I don't think we should share raw data with companies; I think we should let people ask questions that we could answer with the data, and we can determine the degree to which we can safely answer with summaries.

I think we should share a ‚Äòcomplete summary‚Äô with all team members soon, and assuming there is support from core and legal, with the public in due course. I don‚Äôt think we should share the raw data (with or without the free from answers). I think we should have a group of people who can query that data on request from the rust teams
Reason for not sharing the raw data is pure risk aversion
Reason for sharing the complete summary is because I think it is interesting and we should be open by default. I don‚Äôt see any reason to share it with teams but not companies/public
By "complete summary" you mean a summary of every question, rather than the "just the highlights and interesting results" that the blog posts usually give?
Yes
As detailed a summary as we can make of every question
Well I guess without necessarily cross referencing data within a question too
That seems sufficient that people shouldn't need the raw data, yeah. People can always ask if they want more data, and the PII-handling team can decide if they can supply more data.
The questions I have should largely be answered by those summaries, but I suspect I will also personally want a bit of correlation data (e.g. "how does question X break down by company size").
I'd be generally fine with basically blog post style aggregate publication (basically, blog - narrative summary).
I would still push for a (potentially very short) rfc style writeup that we can circulate quickly and use as a basis for a more complete set later.
Yeah, o expect that we should answer that kind of question for teams basically whatever is needed unless it is potentially identifying due to very small subsets or the demand gets overwhelming
I‚Äôd be happy to write up an rfc-style proposal, I‚Äôd rather avoid an actual rfc üòÄ

Yeah, I think it'd be nice to have it circulated more widely (mostly for rust teams given this initial scoping) an rfc sounds like the right fit, but I get the hesitation - we can maybe dump it in some channels as a hackmd or I can probably own the rfc part with a doc in hand

I realize that it‚Äôs was interpreting the term ‚Äúraw data‚Äù as ‚Äúraw aggregate data‚Äù which survey hero already provides to us. I agree that we should not provide actual raw data (i.e., person 4 answered question 4 with‚Ä¶) to everyone, but I do thinking providing raw aggregate data (i.e., the percentages of answers for every question) to everyone is not a bad idea. I can work with Nick on an RFC like document.
Posted a mini RFC: https://github.com/rust-lang/surveys/pull/189
some folks in the reddit post are asking about access to raw data in some form, and the more complete answers generally
